ner for foreign students given by
the Friendly Relations Committee
of the Y. M. C. A. will be held
this year on Tuesday, November
24th. at 6.30 P. M. The speaker
will be Charles D. Hurrey of New
York, it was announced.
Mr. Hurrey is executive secretary of the National Friendly Relations Committee. He has traveled extensively in his work, and
is well known to numerous foreign students.

Winner Of , Stormer
Poster Even.t Named
Last Sunday afternoon the
Barnstormers selected the poster
which they will use for advertising their first production, Secret
Service, to be given December 4
and 5 at the Lyric. The poster
chosen was submitted by Rand
Taylor.
The winning poster portrays
a confederate general, and consequently it was believed that it
carries the spirit of the play
better than any of the others.
Besides, judges declared, Taylor's
lettering was readible, the lettering of many of the others being
modernistic to the extent of being illegible.

team in years, Hopkins is conceded a real chance by .e ven the
most "hard-boiled" sports writers
to win over ::viaryland in the annual grid classic. Confident Jay
rooters are planning to celebrate
a Hopkins' victory at the First
Cotillon, Thanksgiving evening
after the game.
1927 Last Victory

Not since Gardner Mallonee
led a fighting Blue t~am to a
14-13 victory over the Terps in
1927, has interest run so high in
the time-honored fray. Since that
memorable game Jay efforts to
win against the Colleg·e Parkers
have proved futile. Maryland has
emerged victorious in the last
three tilts by odds-on-scores.
However, in every game the Jay
attack has brought Terrapin
rooters to their feet as Maryland
thrusts were repulsed time after
time in the shadow of the Blue
goal posts.
"Inspired football" it has been
c;dled. but whatever it is, couple
it with the obvious power of this
year's I3lue team and you have
the reason for Hopkins rooters'
confidence of a victory.
Jays Outweighed

As has been the case in the
past, the Black and Gold machine
carries a marked physical advantage. Out-weighing the Jays ten
pounds to a man on the line and
hvelve pounds per man in the
backfield, Maryland obviously
holds the eye of the 'dopesters'
in picking a winner. Offsetting
this handicap, Van Orman's boys
have developed such a speedy attack that the 'I:erps will find it
tough going to keep up with them.
The fact that this speed of the
Jays can be kept up is witnessed
by the drive which took the oval
to the Terror goal line in the
closing minutes of the Wes tern
Maryland setto.
The loss to the Green aggregation has instilled in the Jays a desire to come back. That game
also taught the Hopkins men a
lot of valuable football which will
stand them in good stead against
the more experienced Maryland
team.
Relative Strength Compared
Maryland's schedule, including
such teams as Navy, Vanderbilt,
and Kentucky, has provided the
College Parkers with invaluable
football knowledge. The Terps
boast a highly developed aerial
attack, by virtue of which they
beat Navy and tied Kentucky.
However, they have fine set-off
backs in Chalmers, Woods, Poppleman, and Berger, who are well
seconded by Kiernan and May.
All of these men are experienced
ball-toters and will provide plenty

Sir William Osler
November 3, r93i.
To the Editor of the NEWS-LETTER:
Sir:
Your reporter \Yho chatted pleasantly with Professor Frazer in an
interview printed in your issue of
October 30 made a surprising statement. He said "The late Dr. Osler
is reputed to have said that after a
man reaches forty he should be
chloroformed.'.' This remark is interesting for two reasons : for the
remarkable vitality of the legend
that makes it a commonplace in the
thought of a student born some
years after the event; and for the
generous expansion of Dr. Osier's
whimsey with the years.
Of course Dr. Osler said nothing
of the sort. Venerable as forty
may seem to undergraduates and
much as some of their instructors
mav 'seem to them to deserve
euthanasia, nobody thinks the
world would be better off for such
a wholesale termination of the professional career. I heard Dr. Osler's address and remember it well.
_One did not easily forget the man
or his words. He was deliveringFebruary 22, 1905-his public fare- ·
well to his Hopkins colleag-ues before leaving to become Regius Professor at Oxford; and he adopted
a lighter mood and tone to hide the
feeling of sorrow that was inevitable in such a parting. After some
half-serious talk about the desirability of frequent changes in academic
faculties, he confessed to two fixed
ideas, "harmless obsessions" with. which he bored his friends : the
"comparative uselessness o( men
above 40· years of age" and "the
uselessness of men above 60 years
of •age and the incalculable benefit
it would be in commercial, political,
a:1d professional life if, as a matte'·
of course· men stopped work at ti1is
age." The chloroform legend is
based on the following:
"In th~t charming novel, The
Fixed Period, Anthony Trollope
discitsses the practical advantages in
modern life of a return to this ancient usage, and the pk1t hinges on
the admirable scheme ·Of a co:lege
into which ·at sixty men retired for
a · year on contemplation before a
peaceful departure by chloroform.
That incalculable benefits might
follow such a scheme is apparent to
any one who, like myself, is nearing·
the limit, and who has "made a careful study of the calamities which
may befall men during the seventh
and eighth decades."
The newspapers made a sensation
of this and mauy old men-to Osier's distress-took it seriously and
· kit hurt by the news that a famou;
physician thought they were useless
and ought to be chloroformed.
Before he turned to the serious
part of bis address the speaker aliowed himself one more jest. "The
teacher's life should have three

ESTABLISHMENT OF
THE HENRY FUND
IS JUST ANNOUNCED
By Will Of Late Lady Julia
Henry, Fellowships
Are Founded

FOR EXCHANGE OF U.S.,
BRITISH STUDENTS
Four Grants Of £500 Each
To Be Offered
Yearly
Recent announcement has been
made of the establishment of a
fellowship for the exchange of
British and American students in
the interests of "cementing the
bonds of friendship between the
British Empire and the United
States. This fellowship, to be
known as the Charles and Julia,
Henry Fund, was founded by the
will of the late Lady Julia Henry.
Four scholarships, to the
amount of £500 each, are to be
offered annually. Any unmarried
student at an American university, or graduate of such a university, will be eligible. The
awards are to be co-educational,
and preference will be given to
students in the more advanced
stages of their work.
May Study Anything
The Fellow is privileged to
take up the study of any subject
that he or she so desires, provid·ing \that the choice made
meets with the approval of the
Committee of Management of
the British university to which
the Fellow is assigned.
Male Fellows have the option
of attending either Oxford or
Cambridge, and the female ones
may apply for admission in any
college or school regularly admitting women to departments
of study in the universities
named. The Fellowship ceases
upon the marriage of the Fellow.

Winner Of , Stormer
Poster Even.t Named
Last Sunday afternoon the
Barnstormers selected the poster
which they will use for advertising their first production, Secret
Service, to be given December 4
and 5 at the Lyric. The poster
chosen was submitted by Rand
Taylor.
The winning poster portrays
a confederate general, and consequently it was believed that it
carries the spirit of the play
better than any of the others.
Besides, judges declared, Taylor's
lettering was readible, the lettering of many of the others being
modernistic to the extent of being illegible.

team in years, Hopkins is conceded a real chance by .e ven the
most "hard-boiled" sports writers
to win over ::viaryland in the annual grid classic. Confident Jay
rooters are planning to celebrate
a Hopkins' victory at the First
Cotillon, Thanksgiving evening
after the game.
1927 Last Victory

Not since Gardner Mallonee
led a fighting Blue t~am to a
14-13 victory over the Terps in
1927, has interest run so high in
the time-honored fray. Since that
memorable game Jay efforts to
win against the Colleg·e Parkers
have proved futile. Maryland has
emerged victorious in the last
three tilts by odds-on-scores.
However, in every game the Jay
attack has brought Terrapin
rooters to their feet as Maryland
thrusts were repulsed time after
time in the shadow of the Blue
goal posts.
"Inspired football" it has been
c;dled. but whatever it is, couple
it with the obvious power of this
year's I3lue team and you have
the reason for Hopkins rooters'
confidence of a victory.
Jays Outweighed

As has been the case in the
past, the Black and Gold machine
carries a marked physical advantage. Out-weighing the Jays ten
pounds to a man on the line and
hvelve pounds per man in the
backfield, Maryland obviously
holds the eye of the 'dopesters'
in picking a winner. Offsetting
this handicap, Van Orman's boys
have developed such a speedy attack that the 'I:erps will find it
tough going to keep up with them.
The fact that this speed of the
Jays can be kept up is witnessed
by the drive which took the oval
to the Terror goal line in the
closing minutes of the Wes tern
Maryland setto.
The loss to the Green aggregation has instilled in the Jays a desire to come back. That game
also taught the Hopkins men a
lot of valuable football which will
stand them in good stead against
the more experienced Maryland
team.
Relative Strength Compared
Maryland's schedule, including
such teams as Navy, Vanderbilt,
and Kentucky, has provided the
College Parkers with invaluable
football knowledge. The Terps
boast a highly developed aerial
attack, by virtue of which they
beat Navy and tied Kentucky.
However, they have fine set-off
backs in Chalmers, Woods, Poppleman, and Berger, who are well
seconded by Kiernan and May.
All of these men are experienced
ball-toters and will provide plenty

Sir William Osler
November 3, r93i.
To the Editor of the NEWS-LETTER:
Sir:
Your reporter \Yho chatted pleasantly with Professor Frazer in an
interview printed in your issue of
October 30 made a surprising statement. He said "The late Dr. Osler
is reputed to have said that after a
man reaches forty he should be
chloroformed.'.' This remark is interesting for two reasons : for the
remarkable vitality of the legend
that makes it a commonplace in the
thought of a student born some
years after the event; and for the
generous expansion of Dr. Osier's
whimsey with the years.
Of course Dr. Osler said nothing
of the sort. Venerable as forty
may seem to undergraduates and
much as some of their instructors
mav 'seem to them to deserve
euthanasia, nobody thinks the
world would be better off for such
a wholesale termination of the professional career. I heard Dr. Osler's address and remember it well.
_One did not easily forget the man
or his words. He was deliveringFebruary 22, 1905-his public fare- ·
well to his Hopkins colleag-ues before leaving to become Regius Professor at Oxford; and he adopted
a lighter mood and tone to hide the
feeling of sorrow that was inevitable in such a parting. After some
half-serious talk about the desirability of frequent changes in academic
faculties, he confessed to two fixed
ideas, "harmless obsessions" with. which he bored his friends : the
"comparative uselessness o( men
above 40· years of age" and "the
uselessness of men above 60 years
of •age and the incalculable benefit
it would be in commercial, political,
a:1d professional life if, as a matte'·
of course· men stopped work at ti1is
age." The chloroform legend is
based on the following:
"In th~t charming novel, The
Fixed Period, Anthony Trollope
discitsses the practical advantages in
modern life of a return to this ancient usage, and the pk1t hinges on
the admirable scheme ·Of a co:lege
into which ·at sixty men retired for
a · year on contemplation before a
peaceful departure by chloroform.
That incalculable benefits might
follow such a scheme is apparent to
any one who, like myself, is nearing·
the limit, and who has "made a careful study of the calamities which
may befall men during the seventh
and eighth decades."
The newspapers made a sensation
of this and mauy old men-to Osier's distress-took it seriously and
· kit hurt by the news that a famou;
physician thought they were useless
and ought to be chloroformed.
Before he turned to the serious
part of bis address the speaker aliowed himself one more jest. "The
teacher's life should have three
periods-study until 25, investigation until 40, profession until 60, at
which age I would have him retired on a double allowance." May
I rnggest that you have v0u:· reporter try that suggestion on the
next professor to be interviewed on
his birthday? DR. J. C. FRENCH.

ESTABLISHMENT OF
THE HENRY FUND
IS JUST ANNOUNCED
By Will Of Late Lady Julia
Henry, Fellowships
Are Founded

FOR EXCHANGE OF U.S.,
BRITISH STUDENTS
Four Grants Of £500 Each
To Be Offered
Yearly
Recent announcement has been
made of the establishment of a
fellowship for the exchange of
British and American students in
the interests of "cementing the
bonds of friendship between the
British Empire and the United
States. This fellowship, to be
known as the Charles and Julia,
Henry Fund, was founded by the
will of the late Lady Julia Henry.
Four scholarships, to the
amount of £500 each, are to be
offered annually. Any unmarried
student at an American university, or graduate of such a university, will be eligible. The
awards are to be co-educational,
and preference will be given to
students in the more advanced
stages of their work.
May Study Anything
The Fellow is privileged to
take up the study of any subject
that he or she so desires, provid·ing \that the choice made
meets with the approval of the
Committee of Management of
the British university to which
the Fellow is assigned.
Male Fellows have the option
of attending either Oxford or
Cambridge, and the female ones
may apply for admission in any
college or school regularly admitting women to departments
of study in the universities
named. The Fellowship ceases
upon the marriage of the Fellow.
